facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 47 of 1961 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 47 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1960, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court Gwalior Bench in Criminal Revision No. 91/59.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1960, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Bench at Gwalior  in Criminal Revision No. 91/59.

facts.text: Three appellants with five others were tried for offences under s. 4 of the Madhya Bharat Gambling Act, Samvat 2006, Madhya Bharat Act No. 51 of 1949, Samvat 2036.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants with five others were tried for offences under s. 4 of The United State of Gwalior, Indore and Malwa  Madhya Bharat , Gambling Act, Samvat 2006,  Madhya Bharat Act No. 51 of 1949    Samvat 2036 .

facts.text: Krishnachandra, the first appellant, was also tried under s. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Krishnachandra, the first appellant, was also tried under s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: All the original accused except one were convicted under s. 4 of the Act and sentenced to one month's simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: All the original accused except one were companyvicted under s. 4 of the Act and sentenced to one months simple imprisonment.

facts.text: Krishnachandra was convicted in addition under s. 3 of the Act and sentenced to one month's simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: Krishnachandra was companyvicted in addition under s. 3 of the Act and sentenced to one months .simple imprisonment.

facts.text: The sentences in Krishnachandra's case were ordered to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences in Krishna- chandras case were ordered to run companycurrently.

facts.text: All these persons appealed unsuccessfully to the Court of Session.

anchor.surface_text: All these persons appealed unsuccessfully to the Court of Session.

facts.text: The three appellants filed a petition for revision in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants then filed a petition for revision in the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court issued a notice under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to these appellants to show cause why the sentences passed on them should be enhanced.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also issued a numberice under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to these appellants to show cause why the sentences passed on them should number be enhanced.

facts.text: The High Court by its order dated December 14, 1960, dismissed the revision petition filed by the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its order dated December 14, 1960, dismissed the revision petition filed by the appellants

facts.text: High Court imposed a fine of Rs. 200 on each convict for which they were originally convicted.

anchor.surface_text: and in addition to the sentence of imprisonment imposed a fine of Rs. 200 on each companynt or companynts for which they were originally companyvicated.

facts.text: The Appellants asked for a certificate to appeal to this Court but it was refused by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants asked for a certificate to appeal to this Court but it was refused by the High Court.

facts.text: The appellants obtained special leave from this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, however, obtained special leave from this Court and have filed the present appeal.

facts.text: Instruments of gaming were found in the house on a search being made.

anchor.surface_text: It has been amply proved in the present case that on a search being made instruments of gaming were found in the house

facts.text: A presumption under s. 6 was drawn against the persons present there.

anchor.surface_text: and a presumption under s. 6 was therefore drawn against the persons present there.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on January 25, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. January 25. The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

facts.text: The Madhya Bharat Gambling Act is Act No. 51 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Madhya Bharat Act No. 51 of 1949    Samvat 2036 .

facts.text: The three appellants' criminal revision was dismissed by the Madhya Pradesh High Court Gwalior Bench.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Bench , by which a criminal revision filed by the three appellants was dismissed.

facts.text: Only one point was argued before the Supreme Court: that s. 6 of the Gambling Act is ultra vires the Constitution.

holdings.text: Considering the fact that gambling is an evil and it is rampant... the law to root out gambling cannot but be in the public interest. anchor.surface_text: Considering the fact that gambling is an evil and it is rampant, that gaming houses flourish as profitable business and that detection of gambling is extremely difficult, the law to root out gambling cannot but be in the public interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special presumptions justified for eradicating rampant gambling evil given detection difficulties, if safeguards present

holdings.text: In our opinion the Act with which we are concerned contains sufficient safeguards to ensure that there is no danger to any one except to those who are proved to the satisfaction of the Court to keep a gaming house or who can be presumed unless the contrary be proved to be there for the purpose of gaming.
